metadata.title: NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing the NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode property list key, which is a Boolean value that indicates whether an app prefers to run in compatibility mode when necessary on Mac computers with camera housing in the screen bezel. The document explains how the system handles display safe areas and provides guidance for developers on auditing their apps.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: A Boolean value that indicates whether the app prefers to run in compatibility mode when necessary.

On Mac computers that include a camera housing in the screen bezel, the system provides a compatibility mode to prevent apps from unintentionally putting content in the region the housing occupies. When this mode is active, the system changes the active area of the display to avoid the camera housing. The new active area ensures your app's contents are always visible and not obscured by the camera housing. The system activates this compatibility mode when an app that requires it places a window behind the camera housing in the current desktop or full-screen space.

On Mac computers that include a camera housing, the Finder adds a checkbox to your app's Get Info panel to enable or disable compatibility mode. If your app's Info.plist file includes the NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode key, the Finder doesn't add that checkbox; instead, it uses the value of the key to determine whether to run your app in compatibility mode. Set the value of the key to true to always run your app in compatibility mode, and set it to false to never run your app in compatibility mode.

After you audit your app and verify that it runs correctly on Mac computers that include a camera housing, add this key to your Info.plist file and set its value to false. If you discover issues during your audit, add the key and set its value to true until you're able to fix those issues.

content.label: Note
content.text: On Mac computers that include a camera housing in the bezel, the auxiliaryTopLeftArea and auxiliaryTopRightArea properties of NSScreen contain the regions to the left and right of the camera housing. Use those properties and the visibleFrame property to determine where to display your content.

items.definition: A Boolean value that indicates whether the system runs the app using a compatibility mode for UI.
The user interface style for the app.
A Boolean value that indicates whether Core Animation layers use antialiasing when drawing a layer that isn't aligned to pixel boundaries.
The app's white-point adaptivity style, enabled on devices with True Tone displays.
A Boolean value that indicates whether Core Animation sublayers inherit the opacity of their superlayer.
A string value that specifies a system version after which the system ignores the requires full screen key.
A Boolean value that indicates if an iOS or iPadOS app supports Assistive Access.
A Boolean value that indicates if an iOS or iPadOS app appears as full screen in Assistive Access.

pages.pageSummary: This is the Apple Developer Documentation page for the NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode Info.plist key. The page explains that this Boolean property list key controls whether an app runs in compatibility mode on Mac computers with camera housing (notch) in the screen bezel. The documentation describes how the system handles display safe areas, how the Finder manages the compatibility mode checkbox, and provides guidance for developers on auditing their apps. It also includes links to related NSScreen properties for handling the camera housing regions and lists related styling-related Info.plist keys in the See Also section.

keyTerms.definition: A Boolean Info.plist key that indicates whether an app prefers to run in compatibility mode when necessary on Mac computers with camera housing in the screen bezel.
The physical notch area in the screen bezel of certain Mac computers (such as MacBook Pro models with notch displays) that contains the FaceTime camera.
A system mode that changes the active area of the display to avoid the camera housing, ensuring app contents are always visible and not obscured.
An NSScreen property containing the region to the left of the camera housing on Mac computers with a notch display.
An NSScreen property containing the region to the right of the camera housing on Mac computers with a notch display.
An NSScreen property that defines the visible area of the screen, useful for determining where to display content.
The information property list file that contains configuration information for an app bundle.
The Finder window that displays detailed information about a selected file or application, including options to enable/disable compatibility mode.

keyFindings: The NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode key is available on macOS 12.0 and later.
When the key is present in Info.plist, the Finder does not show the compatibility mode checkbox in the Get Info panel.
Setting the key to true forces the app to always run in compatibility mode.
Setting the key to false forces the app to never run in compatibility mode.
Developers should audit their apps on Mac computers with camera housing before setting this key to false.
The system automatically activates compatibility mode when an app that requires it places a window behind the camera housing.
NSScreen provides auxiliaryTopLeftArea, auxiliaryTopRightArea, and visibleFrame properties for handling camera housing regions programmatically.

designDecisions.decision: The system provides automatic compatibility mode to protect legacy apps from content being obscured by camera housing.
designDecisions.rationale: Ensures backward compatibility for apps that were not designed with notch displays in mind.

designDecisions.decision: The Info.plist key overrides the Finder checkbox.
designDecisions.rationale: Allows developers to specify a definitive preference rather than leaving it to user configuration.

designDecisions.decision: Developers should audit before disabling compatibility mode.
designDecisions.rationale: Ensures apps properly handle the camera housing region before opting out of the safety net.
